fields.headline: Ten of the best doppelgängers
fields.bodyText: Private Memoirs and Confessions of a Justified Sinner by James Hogg Robert Wringhim, a self-righteous Calvinist, meets a "strange youth". "What was my astonishment on perceiving that he was the same being as myself!" This "second self" tells Wringhim that, as one of God's "elect", he is above morality and leads him into depravity. Wringhim dies convinced that his double is Satan himself. "William Wilson" by Edgar Allen Poe William, the narrator, meets a boy at his boarding school who is his exact double, and who copies his every mannerism. The strange twin pursues him through life, as he dabbles in darker and darker vices. Maddened by his presence, William stabs him at a masked ball - only to find that his own body is bleeding. The Poor Clare by Elizabeth Gaskell A soldier called Gisborne is cursed when he kills an old woman's beloved dog. The curse falls on his daughter, Lucy, who finds herself accompanied by a double of herself, "a ghastly resemblance" with a "demon soul". The old lady finds out that Lucy is her grand-daughter, and lifts the curse. A Tale of Two Cities by Charles Dickens Sydney Carton is a brilliant but indolent barrister. He discovers he bears an uncanny resemblance to Charles Darnay, a French emigre he has defended against a treason charge. Both men love the same woman, Lucie Manette. Darnay returns to Paris, where he is sentenced to death by guillotine. Carton redeems himself by taking Darnay's place. The Double by Fyodor Dostoevsky This novella concerns the torments of a government clerk, Golyadkin, who finds that an exact double of himself has appeared in St Petersburg and has set out to destroy his reputation. Naturally, the doppelganger has all the social ease that the real Golyadkin lacks. No one else seems to notice the resemblance. Our hero becomes increasingly paranoid and descends into madness. "The Jolly Corner" by Henry James Spencer Brydon becomes convinced an old family house is haunted by his other self - a ghost who is the man he could have been if he had not left to live abroad for several decades. One night he confronts his alter ego. "Rigid and conscious, spectral yet human, a man of his own substance and stature waited there ..." He collapses and wakes in the arms of a good woman. "The Secret Sharer" by Joseph Conrad Conrad's narrator tells how, as the captain of a merchant ship in the Gulf of Siam, he rescued a sailor who is strangely like himself. He calls him "my double", even though he confesses to being on the run having killed a man. Whatever his past, the narrator feels compelled by their likeness to help him. A Wizard of Earthsea by Ursula Le Guin Ged, the wizard of the title, has a doppelganger, an evil "nameless one" who takes on his form. The only way to destroy his double is to find out its true name, which he does by using his native wit. "Magic consists in this, the true naming of a thing." Despair by Vladimir Nabokov Hermann Karlovich, a Russian businessman, tells how, in Prague, he meets a tramp called Felix who looks exactly like him. Hermann suggests a switch of identities - and then murders the gullible Felix for his own life insurance. The perfect crime. Except that the exact resemblance of the two men may be in Hermann's mind only. Aiding and Abetting by Muriel Spark The fugitive Lord Lucan is paired with a double who goes by the name of Walker, but swears that he is Lucan, and shares with him a Paris-based psychiatrist, herself a fraudster. Lucan and his double are locked in mutual need and hatred, and you know that one will eventually destroy the other ...
